importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date of Trump's recent phone call with Putin, which led to the announcement of a potential summit, setting the stage for the subsequent doubts about the meeting's timing.
The date of the previous Trump-Putin summit in Alaska, where initial ceasefire conditions were discussed, and which now serves as a reference point for current disagreements.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Trump previously claimed a meeting with Putin could occur within two weeks, but this timeline has been challenged by both the Kremlin and the White House, casting doubt on feasibility.

keyTakeAways: Doubts have emerged over the likelihood of a swift Trump-Putin summit on ceasefire negotiations in Ukraine.
The Kremlin and White House both state that no plans exist for a meeting in the immediate future, citing the need for serious preparation.

A planned preparatory meeting between Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and US counterpart Marco Rubio has been postponed, with reports indicating US concerns over Moscow’s maximalist ceasefire demands.
Lavrov maintains that Russia has not changed its position since the Alaska summit, asserting that key demands like territorial concessions and Ukraine’s neutrality remain unchanged.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders accuse Russia of stalling peace efforts and continuing attacks, emphasizing that only Ukraine is committed to peace.
Trump has called for a ceasefire by freezing battle lines, a position supported by Ukraine and Europe, but rejected by Putin who insists on hardline territorial demands.
A meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy is seen as necessary by Ukraine, but Russia has ruled out such talks until a peace deal is practically agreed upon.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin is the central figure in the discussion of a ceasefire in Ukraine and is directly involved in negotiations with Trump, whose position on peace is contested.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of the United States (and former)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the focal point of the summit speculation and has publicly claimed a meeting with Putin could happen within two weeks, creating significant political interest and doubt.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Peskov is the official voice of the Kremlin, stating that preparations for a summit could take time and downplaying imminent meetings.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Lavrov is directly involved in ceasefire discussions and has rejected the idea of a new meeting with US counterpart Marco Rubio, citing unchanged Russian demands.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: United States Senator and US Foreign Minister (interim role)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rubio was expected to meet Lavrov in person, but that meeting has been canceled, highlighting US skepticism about Russian peace conditions.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelenskyy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelenskyy is a key proponent of peace and has criticized Russian stalling tactics, calling for direct talks with Putin to make progress.

namedEntities.name: Alaska summit (August 2025)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A prior meeting between Trump and Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Alaska summit established initial ceasefire conditions, which are now being challenged and re-evaluated in the context of current delays and disagreements.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Doubts have emerged over a proposed Trump-Putin summit on Ukraine ceasefire negotiations, as both the Kremlin and the White House state that no immediate plans exist for a meeting. Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov and US officials emphasize the need for serious preparation, contradicting Trump’s claim that a meeting could happen within two weeks. A planned preparatory meeting between Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and US counterpart Marco Rubio has been canceled, with US officials citing concerns over Russia’s maximalist demands. Lavrov maintains that Russia has not changed its position since the August Alaska summit, including demands for territorial concessions and Ukraine’s neutrality. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders criticize Russia for stalling, insisting only Ukraine is committed to peace. Trump has advocated for a ceasefire by freezing battle lines, a position supported by Ukraine and Europe, but rejected by Putin, who continues to insist on hardline terms. A direct meeting between Putin and Zelenskyy is seen as necessary by Ukraine, but Russia has ruled it out until a peace deal is practically agreed upon.
title: Doubts emerge over Trump-Putin Budapest summit
